content.description:
Start in the steep rock just left of a massive beech tree. Power through two stacked boulders to continuous climbing up pockets that leads to a leftward mantle move onto the ramp. Follow the crack feature and run it out to the chains.

A hand-sized cam would remove the run-out up top.
content.location: Starts just left of a large beech tree. The first hand holds are ~6ft off the ground.

content.description: Sequential power endurance on perfect pockets that gets harder the higher up you go. Don't let your guard down 'til you're at the anchor!
content.location: The middle line on the wall in between Cabin Boy Fever and Black Pearl.

content.description: The obvious, striking arete. Bouldery on small holds
content.location: Currently the furthest left route at the crag, to the left of the pinnacle containing Capstan and Kiss the Manta Ray

content.description: This route climbs the pinnacle on good holds. At the top the route traverses left to anchors directly below the summit.
content.location: Follow the left fork of the trail up to the cliff. You will see a pinnacle up against the cliff. This route climbs the face of the pinnacle facing the main part of the cliff.

content.description: Tackle an initial roof, then romp up the slab using the crack for protection/holds.
content.location: 30 feet right of Cabin Boy Fever.

content.description: Great route that breaks right after the start of "Boarding Pass". A tough move off the ground leads to a small ledge followed by fairly sustained climbing on small but solid pockets and underclings. Some holds are sharp and sometimes a little dirty still but overall solid.
content.location: On the far (climbers right) side of the wall. Just after crossing a small creek/depression there is an obvious short bolted left facing crack. Boarding Pass and Castoff are ~30 feet to the right of this.

content.description: Dirty, sandy.  Too much rope drag.   Flakes break.  Lower off Kiss the Manta Ray anchors.
content.location: Same rock, 180 degrees around on the other side as Kiss the Manta Ray

content.description: Start just right of Sail and climb up past a small, sandy ledge to pull on to the sequential, pocketed face. Prepare for a bit of a ride if you pump out on the runout to the chains.
content.location: On the pocketed face right of the detached prow where the trail meets the cliff. Directly right of Sail.

content.description: Big holds through a grove off the deck lead over a slabby bulge. Climb the long face as it steepens and the holds thin out, requiring some pocket pulling and good footwork to stave off the pump. No distinct crux, but challenging to find the best sequences up high.
content.location: Look for an interesting groove near the ground with large knobby holds leading to a 70-80 foot clean face. At the 3rd or 4th bolt, a second line of bolts leads up and right on the 5.10d "Castoff".

content.description: Starts on the first bolt of Sail, then traverse left and up. Big pockets and big moves lead to smaller pockets and crimps on slightly overhanging wall. Rope drag is not really an issue despite the low traverse, especially if using longer draws.
content.location: Starts in an undercut under the first bolt of Sail, then traverses left and up. The left-most route on the wall, just before a huge detached pinnacle.

content.description: Start by squeezing a big block above the chossy roof and grab some cool holds up the mini arêtes to reach a jug ledge. Levitate up the 4-foot section of blank rock to gain a steep, pocketed headwall that wanders up and right. Save some juice for the smaller holds at the end.
content.location: Look for the blank section of rock surrounding the third bolt. Follows the left side of the steep pocketed upper wall just right of "Cabin Boy Fever."

content.description: Follow the juggy crack feature up and left, over a small roof. Good hands, but not much for feet.
content.location: Walk right from the main wall with "Sail" about 300 yards, past a small drainage and some boulders. Locate the obvious bolted crack feature cutting up and left.
